column4: why can't I do "/etc/init.d/mysql start" anymore, and what's the right way to start mysqld?
why can't I do "sudo /etc/init.d/mysql start" anymore, and what's the right way to start mysqld? (some crap about using "service start mysql", but that just hangs)
why can't I do "sudo /etc/init.d/mysql start" anymore, and what's the right way to start mysqld? (some crap about using "service start mysql", but that just hangs)
It says that for all services. I'm not sure why myself.
